entries.name: Ada Lovelace
entries.summary: Ada Lovelace was a 19th-century mathematician regarded as an early computing pioneer for her work on Charles Babbage's Analytical Engine.

entries.name: Alan Turing
entries.summary: Alan Turing was a mathematician and logician, widely considered to be the father of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence.

entries.name: Albert Einstein
entries.summary: Albert Einstein was a German-born theoretical physicist who developed the theory of relativity.

entries.name: Marie Curie
entries.summary: Marie Curie was a Polish-born French physicist and chemist who conducted pioneering research on radioactivity.

entries.name: Nikola Tesla
entries.summary: Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor, electrical engineer, and mechanical engineer who is best known for his contributions to the design of the modern alternating current (AC) electricity supply system.

entries.name: Isaac Newton
entries.summary: Isaac Newton was an English mathematician, physicist, and astronomer who is widely recognized as one of the most influential scientists of all time.

entries.name: Galileo Galilei
entries.summary: Galileo Galilei was an Italian astronomer, physicist, and engineer who played a crucial role in the Scientific Revolution.

entries.name: Leonardo da Vinci
entries.summary: Leonardo da Vinci was an Italian polymath whose areas of interest included invention, painting, sculpting, architecture, science, music, mathematics, engineering, literature, anatomy, geology, astronomy, botany, writing, history, and cartography.
